II Washington, Feb l0.-The Message Of the Pre-
&siden, respecting the concerns OF Georgia and the
&Cfeek Indians, was yesterday taken up an The House


pf Representatives., and the merits of the matter 10


cidentally touched upon, and the subject finally re.
#rrred toa Select Committee. II was very salts
Factory TO observe that. far as could be inferred
from the expression oI opinion, an universal senti


ment seems to exist in favor Of buyug out from the


INDIANS the remnant OF theft title to land in Georgia,
3ho, covered by the Treaty os 1926.


4 This subject occupied the House 10 so late an


hour in the day, that the Order OF the Day, on the

Wool and Woolens. was not reached before the

HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.

Gov. TYLER AND Mn. CLAY.-A report has
lately reached us, witch has staggered our latin N
Gov. TYLER, and which if true, as we are apprehen


sive it will prove will utterly destroy the confidence
we had reposed in him, and cause The Legislature


to repent if they have not already done II, the hour
1 in which they chose him as the successor OF John
Randolph in the Senate of the United States. Inc
report 10 which we allude is this--That Mr. Clay,


within the las, few days stated in conversation with
several gentlemen n, that shortly alter the determine
ton Of the late Presidential election in the House OF
Repre- sen,atives, he received letter from Gov Iy
Ter approvng in unqualified terms OF his, Mr. C's
course, in that election, and congratulatng Mr. =.
and the country upon the result. We have seen o
gentle Of undoubed veracy who had this state
men, from one OF those TO whom Mr.. Clay eommu.
ncated it, and We give il to the public as we rece'v-
ed it, that i. may be fasifed by Gov Tyler, or hs
friends, il untrue. II true, the people of Virgins
have been grossly deceived and imposed upon 10 the


election OF Gov Tyler to The Senase-they diiier
most widely with him as to The propriesy OF Mr..
4 3Clays conduct and would be unwilling to De repre-
sen,ed by him or any other man who thinks win
him on that subject II il should turn out that such


a letter a. that we have described, was written BY
Governor Tyler TO MIR. Clay, we would respectfully
Aenquire whether tha. fact known to the Legs


lature when they entered upon the late election OF
5Senator ?

far from the Legislature "repenting The hour IN

dolph," they will have cause to rejoice IN the act 10

From the Baltimore Gazptte. February 9.


The following letter, from Lima, contains much
commercial Information oil interest, paro ularly in
that part which speaks Of our Domestic Fabrics


Lima, Oct. l. 1896


"The importation Of Flour at present in FIRST
hands and expected in all the monlh OF Octohers
will be about 5000 bartels which should lhink will
bring the price down; at present II to 12 dollars
is asked, on board but few or no sales are made at
that price. Independent of this, Chill Wheat is
rather abundant and The people have not the meaIs
they had formerly. Ii -four is even sold on board
at 80 duties, carriages, &C. will bring it to Sl8 in
Lima. This is considered great sum for q bar
rel OF -four However, they must have the article,
and should think every vesse coming on the coast
should bring small lot, say 1000 barrels or
Several kinds Of English and American goods are
scarce and high here. American Domestics, none
soat or in frat hands. Salins, good quality scarceS
few generally pay--colors white and black, with
few other high co;ors. bat they must be double
satin. Sperm. Candles. and Soap are articles that
few boxes generally pay. Furniture, the place
has been completely stocked With, Of late, but is
now getting scarce.


I'VE generally have list of every vessels cargo
bound to these seas via Panama, about a month or
two before the vessel arrives and conse queny this
information frequently affects the market one way
or another. This does away the virtue OF our mer-
chants secret expeditions.


"Our unbleaehcd a-4 and domestics are gain~
ing ground here daily. and in all cases preerred to
English or India Co,tons. They generally COM
mand living profit at least There have been
samples Of them sent to England for imitation, but
whether they have succeeded we not able TO say
Under the same enclosure you will find new for
mado, or valuation, which is to take effect from
February 9th. 1897, and all articles pay 80 per cent
duty on the valuations except those specified in The
Register Official, No. g. Junio g. Domestics, Lard,
Furniture Saddles, and several other articles, it ap
pears, alter February. 1897. pay duty Of 80 per
cent. on valuation. This will amount to prohibi-
tion except the domestics managed BY putting
them up in the shape of Platllas something else,
and stamping them Cotton Pla,illss or some other
name. / should Think that by managing it this
way, it would be the only way they could be ship
ped. There is to be q new valuation every six
months, so that you will never know the correct
valuations and duties.n
From the Baltimore Gazptte, February 9.

the day OF their death. Gov. tyler. isa Iudicious,
sensible man. and will represent Virginia as she was
won, TO be in the days Of Mr.. JeFerson.1


baltimore Patriot.
The Virginia Jackson Republican Of Monday is
dressed in deep mourning, and tie Feading editorial
article, alter brief caption commences thus; We
are all amazement =! heart sick ~ chapfauenu
dumb!!- Mourn, Virginia. Mourn!." Who's dead
now, asks he reader, !" Mr.. Madison or who?'' Mr.
Madison is not dead-nor even Mr.. Randolph, nor
Mr.. Giles, nor even Thomas Richie; but the
HOPES OF THE RICHMOND PARTY are " deep 10 the
ocean buried' To be plain, the Republican has dis.
covered that Mr.. Tyler, the Senator elected in the
place Of MIR. Randolph, approves Of the manner in
which the present administration camo into power,
and as the Jackson party found their opposition en-
titely upon that basis, Mr.. Tyler 10 lost to them.
The Republican made the discovery in the article
from the Winchester Virgnian, which stated tina,
shortly after the determination Of the late Presi-
dental election in the House Of Representatives MIR.
Clay received letter from Gov. Tyler, approving
in unqualified terms, Of his, (Mr. Clay's) course in
hat election, and congratuating Mr.. Clay and the
country upon the result" The Republican under
stands IRON unquestionable authority" that the
letter :" is in substance acknowledged by Mr.. Ty-
Ter" We thought at the time, that the Republi
cans boast, that the Administration only "swsp
ping the Devil for Witch,' was premature. What
think you Of the bargain Tbs Witch, when sub
ectcd to the ordeal proves no. to be Witch, end
the administration has go the Devil off its hands!
In sober eatnesteess, and party feeling aside,
The election Of Gov. Tyler to the Senate Of the Uni
ted States, in the place OF MIR. Randolph is good
thing for Virginia, the Senate, and the country at
large. ibid.

The gentleman sent by the Governor to confer
with The Little Prince has returned. and brings IN
formation, we understand that the Chief dlsavows


and dlsapproves of the proceedings OF his People, IN
taking the Compasses from the Surveyors whleh
Ihe promised 10 have restored The object OF the
ILuc Prince as stated by himself, appears to have
been, 20 make such protest against the survey OF
the laod between the old and new Treaty lines as
would give the Indians strong claim on the Gene.
raj Government for compensation for ,ha, slip OF
country No further opposition to The survey is
anticipated, and, oi course, we presume, no troops
will be called out Recorder.

Fire.-On Tuesday night last, large stable be-
longing TO the Columbian Hotel, in Richmond Vir.,
was burnt to the ground. and ten horses and TWO
colts perishcd in the flames.


Mr. Fan Buren has been re elected to the U. S.

The editor OF the Alexandria Gazette attend, the
hall Of the House Of Representatives as reporter
In his paper Of Wednesday he says" We witness
ed, last evening, in the House Of Representatives,
one of the most humiliatng scenes that has ever
taken place in that body. Nothing that occurred in
the Senate during the last session could equal it.
Mr. Hamilton was the principal actor, as might be
expected. and so outrageous wss his conduct, that
the question frequently asked, "is the man
crazy or drunk 20 His conduct would have disgra-
ced cock pit.-We returned too late last evening
to go into particulars. but faithful account shall
be given hereafter Amongst other vociserations
we heard for the first time in American AS.
semby, the cry Of hear him--hear him.

The 800. 900 Prize.-We mentioned the other
day that the celebrated ause of Christian Clarke
vs. The Corporation If Washington was before the
Supreme Court OF the u. States. The suit was
instituted for the recovery from the Corporation, Of
prize o the above amount, drawn BY Mt Clarke,
in the Washington Lottery, the Manager OF which
absconded without paying the Prizes. We learn
from the National Ineligencer Of Thursday last
,ha, the case has been decided against the Corpora
ton of Washington. " To many OF our city rea
ders,, (says that paper,) "this decision will have
been une expected. Coming from tribunal consti
tuted as Supreme Court is, no one can question
the impar,iality Of the judgment, heavy and hard
az il is on those who have TO suffer the consequences
and blis htng il may be TO the openipg prospects
OF this infant City. The loss which The city will
thus have sustained by the failure OF the contractor
for the lottery, will amount, as We are informed, to
upwards OF one hundred and fifty thousand dollars,
fincluding. Of course, all demands resting ON the
same foundation as that oil Mr. Clarke.)


The Greeks.-One hundred and ten dollars and
sf,y cents have been collected in the Baptist Church
in New York under the pastoral care OF the Rev.
Mr. Cone for the benefit OF the Greeks.


Mr. Tilliarn Poole, of this Borough in letter to
the Greek Committee of Philadelphia, states that
the collections here have not been successful as
was anticipated. He mentions that about 25 barrels
Fof -four and mddlings will be forwarded as soon as

Gov. TYLER AND Mn. CLAY.-A report has
lately reached us, witch has staggered our latin N
Gov. TYLER, and which if true, as we are apprehen


sive it will prove will utterly destroy the confidence
we had reposed in him, and cause The Legislature


to repent if they have not already done II, the hour
1 in which they chose him as the successor OF John
Randolph in the Senate of the United States. Inc
report 10 which we allude is this--That Mr. Clay,


within the las, few days stated in conversation with
several gentlemen n, that shortly alter the determine
ton Of the late Presidential election in the House OF
Repre- sen,atives, he received letter from Gov Iy
Ter approvng in unqualified terms OF his, Mr. C's
course, in that election, and congratulatng Mr. =.
and the country upon the result. We have seen o
gentle Of undoubed veracy who had this state
men, from one OF those TO whom Mr.. Clay eommu.
ncated it, and We give il to the public as we rece'v-
ed it, that i. may be fasifed by Gov Tyler, or hs
friends, il untrue. II true, the people of Virgins
have been grossly deceived and imposed upon 10 the


election OF Gov Tyler to The Senase-they diiier
most widely with him as to The propriesy OF Mr..
4 3Clays conduct and would be unwilling to De repre-
sen,ed by him or any other man who thinks win
him on that subject II il should turn out that such


a letter a. that we have described, was written BY
Governor Tyler TO MIR. Clay, we would respectfully
Aenquire whether tha. fact known to the Legs


lature when they entered upon the late election OF
5Senator ?

4 ton paper. OF Gov. yfer's high opinion OF Nr.


Clay and OF his approval of his conduct on the Pre-


sidental question, we have before been apprised 30


far from the Legislature "repenting The hour IN
which they chose him as the successor oil John han-


dolph," they will have cause to rejoice IN the act 10

full articles.headline: From the Baltimore Gazptte, February 9.
full articles.article:
From the Baltimore Gazptte. February 9.


The following letter, from Lima, contains much
commercial Information oil interest, paro ularly in
that part which speaks Of our Domestic Fabrics


Lima, Oct. l. 1896


"The importation Of Flour at present in FIRST
hands and expected in all the monlh OF Octohers
will be about 5000 bartels which should lhink will
bring the price down; at present II to 12 dollars
is asked, on board but few or no sales are made at
that price. Independent of this, Chill Wheat is
rather abundant and The people have not the meaIs
they had formerly. Ii -four is even sold on board
at 80 duties, carriages, &C. will bring it to Sl8 in
Lima. This is considered great sum for q bar
rel OF -four However, they must have the article,
and should think every vesse coming on the coast
should bring small lot, say 1000 barrels or
Several kinds Of English and American goods are
scarce and high here. American Domestics, none
soat or in frat hands. Salins, good quality scarceS
few generally pay--colors white and black, with
few other high co;ors. bat they must be double
satin. Sperm. Candles. and Soap are articles that
few boxes generally pay. Furniture, the place
has been completely stocked With, Of late, but is
now getting scarce.


I'VE generally have list of every vessels cargo
bound to these seas via Panama, about a month or
two before the vessel arrives and conse queny this
information frequently affects the market one way
or another. This does away the virtue OF our mer-
chants secret expeditions.


"Our unbleaehcd a-4 and domestics are gain~
ing ground here daily. and in all cases preerred to
English or India Co,tons. They generally COM
mand living profit at least There have been
samples Of them sent to England for imitation, but
whether they have succeeded we not able TO say
Under the same enclosure you will find new for
mado, or valuation, which is to take effect from
February 9th. 1897, and all articles pay 80 per cent
duty on the valuations except those specified in The
Register Official, No. g. Junio g. Domestics, Lard,
Furniture Saddles, and several other articles, it ap
pears, alter February. 1897. pay duty Of 80 per
cent. on valuation. This will amount to prohibi-
tion except the domestics managed BY putting
them up in the shape of Platllas something else,
and stamping them Cotton Pla,illss or some other
name. / should Think that by managing it this
way, it would be the only way they could be ship
ped. There is to be q new valuation every six
months, so that you will never know the correct
valuations and duties.n

the day OF their death. Gov. tyler. isa Iudicious,
sensible man. and will represent Virginia as she was
won, TO be in the days Of Mr.. JeFerson.1


baltimore Patriot.
The Virginia Jackson Republican Of Monday is
dressed in deep mourning, and tie Feading editorial
article, alter brief caption commences thus; We
are all amazement =! heart sick ~ chapfauenu
dumb!!- Mourn, Virginia. Mourn!." Who's dead
now, asks he reader, !" Mr.. Madison or who?'' Mr.
Madison is not dead-nor even Mr.. Randolph, nor
Mr.. Giles, nor even Thomas Richie; but the
HOPES OF THE RICHMOND PARTY are " deep 10 the
ocean buried' To be plain, the Republican has dis.
covered that Mr.. Tyler, the Senator elected in the
place Of MIR. Randolph, approves Of the manner in
which the present administration camo into power,
and as the Jackson party found their opposition en-
titely upon that basis, Mr.. Tyler 10 lost to them.
The Republican made the discovery in the article
from the Winchester Virgnian, which stated tina,
shortly after the determination Of the late Presi-
dental election in the House Of Representatives MIR.
Clay received letter from Gov. Tyler, approving
in unqualified terms, Of his, (Mr. Clay's) course in
hat election, and congratuating Mr.. Clay and the
country upon the result" The Republican under
stands IRON unquestionable authority" that the
letter :" is in substance acknowledged by Mr.. Ty-
Ter" We thought at the time, that the Republi
cans boast, that the Administration only "swsp
ping the Devil for Witch,' was premature. What
think you Of the bargain Tbs Witch, when sub
ectcd to the ordeal proves no. to be Witch, end
the administration has go the Devil off its hands!
In sober eatnesteess, and party feeling aside,
The election Of Gov. Tyler to the Senate Of the Uni
ted States, in the place OF MIR. Randolph is good
thing for Virginia, the Senate, and the country at
large. ibid.

full articles.headline: .Wilietl-erille, (Geo. Jan. 60.
full articles.article:
.HIteHTPCtte, I UeU.I 'H7t' -5


The gentleman sent by the Governor to confer
with The Little Prince has returned. and brings IN
formation, we understand that the Chief dlsavows


and dlsapproves of the proceedings OF his People, IN
taking the Compasses from the Surveyors whleh
Ihe promised 10 have restored The object OF the
ILuc Prince as stated by himself, appears to have
been, 20 make such protest against the survey OF
the laod between the old and new Treaty lines as
would give the Indians strong claim on the Gene.
raj Government for compensation for ,ha, slip OF
country No further opposition to The survey is
anticipated, and, oi course, we presume, no troops
will be called out Recorder.

correspondent justly complains of the Indifference
which the people of this manifest in regard to their
suffering fellow ci zens of Alexandria, who, many years
ago, when Wilmington visited by The Yellow Fever,
con,ribu ed literally the relief of its afflicted inhabitants
II IS not vet to late TO express our gratitude, and
will be adopted TO remove the reproach
which v be upon town, should our indifference
on This subject continue any longer

ouns passed by the General Assembly OF this State at

full articles.headline: BY THIS DAYS SOUTHERN MAIL.
full articles.article:
Congress.-The Senate did not sit on Saturday
In the House Of Representatives the bill to revise
and regulate the duties on imported Wool and Man.
ufac,ures of Wool, was passed BY majority Of
eleven votes. The vote was-Yeas, Io6. Nays, 95.
It's fate in the Senate is however, believed to be
doubtful.

DIED-On the 28th ult., in the 58h year Of his age
Mr. WILLIAM HARRIS, Of Chestertown, Kent County,
Nd.


AT Paris the 14h December, MIR. MALTE
BRUN distinguished French Author particularly in the
DEP Of Geography of the contributors TO the
.Journa des Debats" and OF the Editors othe An
nails des Voyages de la Geographic, ct de pHsoire

the navigation opens. Haye our citizens coatribut
ed all they intend toa


The inhabitants Of Newark, N. J. have subscribed
$1,000 for the Greeks.


Fire.-On Tuesday night last, large stable be-
longing TO the Columbian Hotel, in Richmond Vir.,
was burnt to the ground. and ten horses and TWO
colts perishcd in the flames.


Mr. Fan Buren has been re elected to the U. S.
Senate.


The editor OF the Alexandria Gazette attend, the
hall Of the House Of Representatives as reporter
In his paper Of Wednesday he says" We witness
ed, last evening, in the House Of Representatives,
one of the most humiliatng scenes that has ever
taken place in that body. Nothing that occurred in
the Senate during the last session could equal it.
Mr. Hamilton was the principal actor, as might be
expected. and so outrageous wss his conduct, that
the question frequently asked, "is the man
crazy or drunk 20 His conduct would have disgra-
ced cock pit.-We returned too late last evening
to go into particulars. but faithful account shall
be given hereafter Amongst other vociserations
we heard for the first time in American AS.
semby, the cry Of hear him--hear him.

Friday, February 9.
IN SENATE.
Mr.. Chambers presented the memorial OF the


coonza,ion Society, for aid in its objects, and NOV
La i,s reference to Select Committee.
Il Mr.. Chambers supported the reference at consld
erable length and expressed his high app oba,ion
cf ,he designs OF the Colonization Society. He was
followed BY Mr.. Hayne, who opposed the conside-
ration Of the subject at this time for the reason,


hmonpst others, that, from the late period OF the
Mession, it @s impossible that an opportunity could
HE afforded 6 investigate the subject thoroughly.
$1Vhen. on motion of Mr.. Benton, who made few
Eremarks. adverse to the petition, and the attempt to


sct on il this session, the memorial was laid on the
stabIe.

Amongst the various Splendid Schemes that claim

The 800. 900 Prize.-We mentioned the other
day that the celebrated ause of Christian Clarke
vs. The Corporation If Washington was before the
Supreme Court OF the u. States. The suit was
instituted for the recovery from the Corporation, Of
prize o the above amount, drawn BY Mt Clarke,
in the Washington Lottery, the Manager OF which
absconded without paying the Prizes. We learn
from the National Ineligencer Of Thursday last
,ha, the case has been decided against the Corpora
ton of Washington. " To many OF our city rea
ders,, (says that paper,) "this decision will have
been une expected. Coming from tribunal consti
tuted as Supreme Court is, no one can question
the impar,iality Of the judgment, heavy and hard
az il is on those who have TO suffer the consequences
and blis htng il may be TO the openipg prospects
OF this infant City. The loss which The city will
thus have sustained by the failure OF the contractor
for the lottery, will amount, as We are informed, to
upwards OF one hundred and fifty thousand dollars,
fincluding. Of course, all demands resting ON the
same foundation as that oil Mr. Clarke.)


The Greeks.-One hundred and ten dollars and
sf,y cents have been collected in the Baptist Church
in New York under the pastoral care OF the Rev.
Mr. Cone for the benefit OF the Greeks.


Mr. Tilliarn Poole, of this Borough in letter to
the Greek Committee of Philadelphia, states that
the collections here have not been successful as
was anticipated. He mentions that about 25 barrels
Fof -four and mddlings will be forwarded as soon as
